image.altText: Peter Garrett sings into a microphone on stage, dressed in a blue shirt under colourful orange and red lights.

props.synopsis: The Melbourne Symphony Orchestra's managing director has left the organisation, amid controversy over the orchestra's handling of a pianist's onstage comments about the war in Gaza.

title.children: Peter Garrett to investigate Melbourne Symphony Orchestra in wake of controversial handling of pianist's Gaza comments

image.altText: John Setka sitting behind a number of microphones at a Melbourne media conference.

props.synopsis: Mr Setka claims former Workplace Relations Minister Tony Burke agreed to forgo appointing administrators to the CFMEU in exchange for the union boss's resignation.

title.children: PM says former union boss' claim he was left 'trembling' after elevator conversation is 'nonsense'

image.altText: Jumps racing

props.synopsis: Racing Victoria has conceded its "safety record regressed" in the 2024 jumps racing season after three horses had to be euthanased on a single day of racing at Ballarat.

title.children: 'Deadly day' at Victorian regional race meeting sees three horses put down and two jockeys injured

image.altText: A young girl wearing a grey hat

props.synopsis: A major Melbourne health service has admitted to failures in the lead-up to the death of patient eight-year-old Amrita Lanka in April 2022.

title.children: Melbourne hospital admits failures in Amrita Lanka's death as inquest begins

image.altText: Police tape at a crime scene

props.synopsis: Victoria Police say a pair of women have been arrested over two carjacking incidents in Cranbourne in Melbourne's south-east on Sunday night.

title.children: Melbourne man hospitalised with life-threatening injuries after carjacking and stabbing attack

image.altText: Bill Stevens, 96, instructs an aqua aerobics class at Aquarena  Aquatic and Leisure Centre.

props.synopsis: Aqua aerobics instructor Bill Stevens, 96, is in high demand, but he's not alone. Classes around the country sometimes fill up within minutes, leaving some enthusiasts high and dry.

title.children: Bill, 96, is making his mark leading fitness classes around Melbourne

image.altText: A screenshot of a website interface showing a calendar

props.synopsis: Healthcare clinic patients have received emails that carry the templates of their medical provider, asking them to click on a link to claim a fake prize.

title.children: Hackers target medical software for spam email send to healthcare clients

image.altText: A blue car with crash damage sits on the road. Police tape surrounds the scene.

props.synopsis: Police have charged Antony Benson with multiple offences after he allegedly stabbed a woman and crashed a car at Engadine in Sydney's south.

title.children: Man charged after allegedly stabbing woman while driving in Sydney's south

image.altText: A large kangaroo outside a house.

props.synopsis: A woman who came face-to-face with an aggressive kangaroo while on a run in Victoria, and a passer-by who came to help her, spent 40 frightening minutes trying to escape. So how should you deal with an angry roo? Wildlife carers share some tips.

title.children: Run away or lie on the ground? Here's what wildlife carers say you should do if attacked by an angry roo

image.altText: A man and a woman laughing.

props.synopsis: Months after Australian aid worker Zomi Frankcom was killed in an Israeli air strike, her brother Mal sits down with 7.30 to discuss the missing pieces of the puzzle the Israeli government still has not shared.

title.children: Inside the hour of misery that changed the lives of the Frankcom family

image.altText: A smiling, short-statured woman holds the reins of a small horse.

props.synopsis: Macey will be towered over by her rivals when she steps into the arena at Versailles, but rider Bridget Murphy couldn't care less.

title.children: This tiny horse was deemed too small to ride. Now she is headed for the Paralympics

image.altText: Telegram founder Pavel Durov

props.synopsis: The founder of encrypted messaging service Telegram has been detained in France as part of an investigation into a lack of moderation and criminal use of the platform.

title.children: Telegram's CEO Pavel Durov has been arrested. Here's what to know about the app and its founder

image.altText: Hawthorn v Western Bulldogs

props.synopsis: The Hawks will play their first Friday night game in two years, after the AFL confirmed the week one schedule for the 2024 finals series.

title.children: AFL releases finals fixture as league heavyweights get their first Friday night clash in two years

image.altText: A stock trader looks down at a tablet as he works on the floor of a busy stock exchange while surrounded by screens.

props.synopsis: The ASX200 is up 0.7pc, with health insurer NIB punished despite a 67 per cent increase in profit. It comes after US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's comments about cutting rates lifted global markets on Friday. Follow live.

title.children: ASX up 0.7pc as NIB shares dumped despite profit increase

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: ASX closes up 0.8% , catching Wall Street's wave
ASX 200 up 0.5% heading into the afternoon

image.altText: A group of men in red berets stand in a huddle

props.synopsis: Hezbollah and Israel’s war is escalating. Four Corners travelled to Lebanon’s Hezbollah heartland and found a group determined to hit back.

title.children: Inside Hezbollah’s heartland, a new front line in the Middle East’s escalating conflict

image.altText: Women with a car

props.synopsis: Road safety researchers want maximum speed limits in built-up areas cut, saying it has saved lives overseas.

title.children: Push to reduce speed limits in built-up areas from 50kph to as low as 30kph

image.altText: Surfers and swimmers in the water at Bondi Beach in calm conditions.

props.synopsis: It's winter in Australia, but as you've probably noticed, the weather is unusually warm. The top temperatures over large parts of the country this weekend were well above average for this time of year.

title.children: 40 degrees in August? Here's why it's ridiculously hot right now

image.altText: A head and shoulders shot of a smiling woman.

props.synopsis: A woman accused of digging her housemate's grave after she was allegedly murdered in a local park is granted bail from Hakea Prison.

title.children: Woman charged with digging housemate's grave granted bail from male-only prison

image.altText: Maggie Beer joins two female residents at the dining hall of an aged care home in Perth.

props.synopsis: In a statement on social media on Sunday night, her family said she fell at home, sustaining minor bone fractures and related injuries.

title.children: Australian food icon Maggie Beer injured after fall at home

image.altText: A close up of a man with blonde hair smiling with his dog on a porch.

props.synopsis: The right to disconnect means you can reasonably refuse to be contacted outside of work hours. For people tied to the 'digital leash' of phones and email this marks a substantial boost in their right to break free.

title.children: You have the right to disconnect from work after hours from today. But what does that mean in practice?

image.altText: Photo of smiling man with black jumper and beard.

props.synopsis: Giuliano Pirone collapsed in a shower after an early morning session at a Perth 24-hour gym and was only found that night after his mother raised the alarm.

title.children: Bodybuilder in coma after collapsing in gym shower and left undiscovered for 15 hours with water running

image.altText: Jenna Ortega in Wednesday

props.synopsis: Plus Chappell Roan tells "superfans" to back off (again), Macklemore cancels his Dubai gig in solidarity with Sudan and more entertainment news you might have missed.

title.children: Wednesday’s Jenna Ortega says she quit Twitter after seeing explicit AI images of her teen self

image.altText: Coffs Harbour Local Court

props.synopsis: A court hears Lisa Marie Cummings from Nambucca, NSW was in breach of bail for another offence when she was charged with the murder of a 62-year-old man.

title.children: Woman accused of murder in breach of bail when arrested over body found in surfboard bag

image.altText: A 17th-century classical painting, showing a woman, arms outstretched, and a mostly naked man lying in front of her.

props.synopsis: When conservators at the National Gallery of Victoria X-rayed a 17th-century artwork, they discovered a strange swirl in the right-hand corner. A little investigation ultimately revealed a hidden painting.

title.children: An Australian gallery acquired this painting in the 50s. They only recently discovered its secret

image.altText: Rhiannon Clarke, WAIS athlete and paralympian, poses in the WAIS indoor running track

props.synopsis: Rhiannon Clarke is a two-time Commonwealth Games medallist, a three-time World Championship medallist and now a dual Paralympian, but that's not how she measures her greatest success.

title.children: Rhiannon Clarke is chasing gold in Paris, but her greatest success won't be found on the track

image.altText: Selfie portrait of a bearded man in helmet and bullet-proof vest

props.synopsis: A British safety adviser working with a team of journalists is dead after a Russian missile struck a hotel in the Ukrainian city of Kramatorsk.

title.children: Reuters safety adviser killed and two journalists injured in strike on Ukrainian hotel

image.altText: Ben O'Connor celebrates his red jersey during the La Vuelta

props.synopsis: Australian star Ben O'Connor has increased his lead in the Vuelta a Espana after navigating the Sierra Nevada mountains in sweltering conditions.

title.children: 'We were all a little bit cooked': Ben O'Connor defies odds to increase Vuelta a Espana lead in brutal conditions

image.altText: Oasis mebers during a press op in Hong Kong 2006

props.synopsis: The brothers behind one of the biggest bands of the nineties have hinted they don't look back in anger and a reunion is on the cards.

title.children: Cryptic social media posts by Liam and Noel Gallagher spark rumours Oasis could reunite

image.altText: A man wearing a turban and pale red shirt holds a woman with a black shirt and black hair with her back to the camera

props.synopsis: Pawanjeet Heir was treated like a slave as she pursued the requirements for permanent residency in Australia. Her husband says she has been punished for speaking up.

title.children: Pawanjeet Heir's boss was running a migration scam. Speaking up put her visa at risk

image.altText: Yellow billboard next to busy street

props.synopsis: The Jacqui Lambie Network's implosion in Tasmania follows a growing list of Australian namesake parties that have quickly encountered turbulence.

title.children: Does the Lambie implosion show that 'personality politics' is doomed to fail?

image.altText: A digital board with multiple rows reading "cancelled".

props.synopsis: A long-awaited blueprint for the aviation sector has been handed down, with a promise to establish a charter of rights for customers to seek cash refunds when their flights are cancelled or unreasonably delayed.

title.children: Australians will be able to get cash refunds for delayed and cancelled flights under government crackdown

image.altText: A woman with short blonde hair wearing a gold tracksuit top hands a tall baton to a young girl.

props.synopsis: Commonwealth Games Australia (CGA) oversees the allocation of millions of dollars of funding to different sports and has roles pushing for green and gold success at international events — but behind the scenes its boardroom has become divided.

title.children: The governance dispute that's split the top ranks of Australia's peak Commonwealth Games body

image.altText: Two wraps presented on a plate, filled with lettuce, tomato, beef and sauce

props.synopsis: When you need a lunch on the go or something quick for a dinner, few things are as convenient and versatile as wraps or tortillas.

title.children: Why do wraps last so long and are they healthy?

image.altText: A group of women wearing bathing suits, caps and goggles walking towards the sea.

props.synopsis: Before dawn, Williamstown Beach in Melbourne's inner west is alive with the giggles of those braving the winter seawater, who turn out each day regardless of the weather forecasts, or the warnings issued by Victoria's Environment Protection Agency.

title.children: At a beach in Melbourne's industrial west, 'pollution is a concern' but it rarely stops these swimmers
